info.headline: Flood Advisory issued August 29 at 6:45PM EDT until August 29 at 9:00PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 1230 AM EDT WEDNESDAY... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...A portion of piedmont North Carolina, including the following county, Mecklenburg. * WHEN...Until 1230 AM EDT. * IMPACTS...Nuisance flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to streams and other poor-drainage areas, including parks, greenways, golf courses, underpasses, and parking lots. Isolated, shallow flows over roadways is possible. A few flood-prone, low-water crossings may become impassible. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 644 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms across the Charlotte metro. These storms are producing 1-2 inches of rainfall within an hour, which will result in excessive runoff and rapid rises on small streams and drainages in the area. Expect impacts to common, flood- prone areas along several streams including Little Sugar Creek, Briar Creek, and Irwin Creek to develop over the next 30-60 minutes as these streams and their associated tributaries respond to the heavy rainfall. - Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1 inch are expected over the area as these storms move very slowly over the Charlotte area. Isolated heavier totals are possible. A Flash Flood Warning may be required if these storms do not dissipate or move away from the area quickly enough. Please stay weather aware and be prepared to seek higher ground if you are in an area vulnerable to flooding. - Some locations that may experience flooding include... Uptown Charlotte, Central Charlotte, South Charlotte, East Charlotte, Southwest Charlotte, Northeast Charlotte, Northwest Charlotte, West Concord, Belmont, Pineville, Harrisburg, Freedom Park, The Plaza, Southpark Mall, Hidden Valley, Paw Creek, The Arboretum, Reedy Creek Park and University City. - Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Stay away or be swept away. River banks and culverts can become unstable and unsafe.
